TEXT:
Chief Complaint: 69 yom  with h/o CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin, DM-II
   presenting to ED with acute onset of flank pain.  Workup in the ED
   revealed right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular
   hemorrhage.  Since admission to the floor, he has received a total of 3
   units PRBC's and 6 units FFP in attempt to support patient and reverse
   INR.  Patients urine output has continued to fall and he remains
   minimally responsive to high dose Lasix bolluses.  Patient also began
   to experience asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular
   tachycardia with alternating axis
   24 Hour Events:
   - CT abd/pelvis: no significant change from prior study, areas of
   subcapsular and intraparenchymal hemorrhage without sig. increase in RP
   hematoma, small right pleural effusion, increased opacity at left lung
   base c/w atelectasis vs. aspiration
   - renal recs: urine sediment c/w ATN, dose meds for GFR = 0, agree w/
   diuretic trial
   - urology recs: reverse INR, f/u CT on Monday, follow serial HCT, will
   require MR in 3 months for further evaluation
   - bladder pressure inc. to 21 (stable), general surgery contact[**Name (NI) **] which
   reports no intervention unless > 30
   - HCT  trends down: 38.6 -> 29.5 -> 27.0 -> 25.3 -> 20.2 (1 unit) ->
   21.0 (2 units)-> 26.2 = 3 units total
   - INR trends down: 2.5 -> 2.3 -> 2.4 -> 2.2 -> 1.8 = 6 units FFP
   - Lasix boluses 80mg then 120 mg with UOP around 30 cc/hr
   - episode of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with shifting axis,
   electrolytes normal, patient asymptomatic and exam unremarkable, VSS,
   cardiac enzymes cycled and 1st set normal
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Pantoprazole (Protonix) - [**2190-10-31**] 08:05 PM
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2190-10-31**] 10:32 PM
   Hydromorphone (Dilaudid) - [**2190-11-1**] 03:10 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2190-11-1**] 05:52 AM

                             [**2190-10-31**]  04:47 AM
                             [**2190-10-31**]  12:28 PM
                             [**2190-10-31**]  06:09 PM
                             [**2190-11-1**]  01:55 AM
   WBC
   13.9
   12.1
   Hct
   25.3
   20.2
   21.0
   26.2
   Plt
   158
   122
   Cr

   0.02
   0.02

   0.06
   Glucose
   265
   255
   244
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.1/28.6/1.9, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:228/7/0.06, Ca++:7.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:5.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   .
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code: presumed full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 10486**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10487**]
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2190-10-31**] 08:11 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. He has received 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma to support his blood pressure and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR). His urine output has decreased, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose lasix boluses.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Progressive Renal Failure: The patient's decreased urine output and increasing creatinine levels suggest progressive renal failure. This is concerning, as it may be related to the ongoing bleed affecting renal perfusion.
2. Urological Complications: The patient's retroperitoneal bleed may be related to a renal cyst or other urological pathology. Further evaluation by urology is needed to determine the cause of the bleed and to assess the patient's ongoing risk of complications.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient's volume overload and possible aspiration event may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease increases his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's nausea and vomiting may be related to his ongoing bleed or other gastrointestinal pathology. Further evaluation and management are needed to prevent gastrointestinal complications.
6. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and left shift may indicate infection, which needs to be evaluated and treated promptly to prevent sepsis.
7. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's ongoing bleed and decreased platelet count increase his risk of hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding into other organs or tissues.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's ongoing management requires close monitoring of his vital signs, fluid status, and renal function. Further evaluation by urology is needed to determine the cause of the bleed and to assess the patient's ongoing risk of complications. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and prophylactic measures should be taken to prevent respiratory complications. Cardiovascular and gastrointestinal complications should also be closely monitored and managed promptly. Infection should be evaluated and treated promptly to prevent sepsis. Finally, the patient's code status should be discussed with his family and documented in his medical record.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - hold on repeat CT scan this AM as patient does not appear stable for
   study
   - consult with urology re: need for CT and how it would change
   management
   - q 6  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   - continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - f/u KUB for evaluate of ileus
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - attempt Lasix 120  mg IV bolus in hopes of mobilizing fluid off lungs
   - close renal contact re: management of ARF and consideration of HD
   - renally dose all medications
   ## Hypoxia:  patient initially presented with desaturations in the ED
   with concern for volume overload as evidenced by CXR.  Patient had TTE
   performed to evaluate for cardiac function which was limited but which
   did not suggest decompensated heart failure.  Of note, patient also has
   history of obstructive lung disease and requires BiPAP at night for
   OSA.  Patient now saturating in low-mid 90
s on 4L NC.
   - continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
   - attempt diuresis as discussed above
   - continue scheduled nebulizer treatments
   - prepare for endotracheal intubation of respiratory status becomes
   worse
   - consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration PNA given episode of
   emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening CXR
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - attempt rate control with metoprolol / diltiazem
   - consult EP for pacer interrogation
   - continue to holding ASA in setting of RP bleed
   - restart home dose Metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 7**]
   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated without
   obvious infectious source.  This may represent demargination from
   generalized inflammatory response given RP bleed.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
   ## Concern for UGIB:  patient had single reported episode of guiac
   positive post-tussive emesis in setting of severe cough.  Of note,
   patient has no risk factors variceal bleed and no history suggestive of
   UGIB.  Suspicion for UGIB is very low.
   - check stool guiac
 if positive will require GI consult
   - continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**] for now
   # CHF: unclear to extent of disease with last documented LVEF > 55%.
   TTE performed on day of admission showed mild progression of LVEF
   dysfunction.
   - continue scheduled albuterol and atrovent nebs
   - continue to attempt diuresis
   - formal echo for better evaluation of cardiac function
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Sugars have been poorly controlled in the mid-upper 200
   - increase AM Lantus to 44 units for improved basal coverage with HISS
   for breakthrough
   - contact [**Name (NI) 631**] re: DM management
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   # Access: attain better access with 16 gauge peripheral IV
s vs.
   Midline

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's urine output has continued to fall, and creatinine levels have risen to 5.8 mg/dL, indicating a high risk of ARF. The patient has received 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma to support hemodynamics and reverse INR, but further management is needed to prevent or treat ARF.
2. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's urine sediment is consistent with ATN, and the rising creatinine levels suggest that ATN is likely contributing to the patient's renal failure.
3. Hypoxia: The patient has mild bibasilar atelectasis and a tiny right pleural effusion on CXR, which may be contributing to his hypoxia. The patient's oxygen saturation is in the low-mid 90s on 4L NC, and he may require further oxygen therapy or intubation if his respiratory status worsens.
4. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient has had several episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with shifting axis, which may be related to his underlying AFib. The patient's cardiac enzymes are normal, but further management is needed to control his heart rate and rhythm.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has had a single episode of guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis, which may indicate upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's risk factors for variceal bleeding are low, but further evaluation and management are needed to rule out upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's bladder pressure is increasing, and he has marked right flank tenderness, which may indicate abdominal compartment syndrome. Further monitoring and management are needed to prevent or treat this complication.
7. Infection: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and he has had several episodes of fever, which may indicate an underlying infection. Further evaluation and management are needed to identify and treat any potential infections.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he may require intubation if his oxygenation and ventilation continue to deteriorate.
9. Cardiac Failure: The patient has a history of systolic heart failure, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, but further evaluation and management are needed to assess the extent of his cardiac disease and prevent further deterioration.

The patient's medical team should continue to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to adjust his management plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. He has received 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma to support his hemodynamics and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient's urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose lasix boluses. He has also experienced asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 25.3%
* Platelet count: 158 K/uL
* Creatinine: 5.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.06 ng/mL
* Glucose: 265 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute renal failure (ARF) with oliguria and rising creatinine
* Hypoxia with mild bibasilar atelectasis and a tiny right pleural effusion
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
* Fever and leukocytosis without an obvious infectious source
* Concern for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) due to guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis
* Chronic renal failure with marginal urine output

The patient's medications include:

* Lasix (furosemide) for diuresis
* Hydromorphone (dilaudid) for pain management
* Pantoprazole (protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Levothyroxine sodium for hypothyroidism
* Allopurinol for gout
* Lantus for diabetes mellitus type II

The patient's plan includes:

* Hold on repeat CT scan this morning as he does not appear stable for the study
* Consult with urology regarding the need for a CT scan and how it would change management
* Trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal compartment syndrome
* Continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
* Attempt diuresis with lasix boluses
* Prepare for endotracheal intubation if respiratory status worsens
* Consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration pneumonia given episode of emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening chest X-ray

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to poor perfusion and acute renal failure
* Respiratory failure due to hypoxia and potential aspiration pneumonia
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) due to guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis
* Abdominal compartment syndrome due to rising intra-abdominal pressure
* Septic shock due to sepsis and potential multi-organ failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) on coumadin, who presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain. He was found to have an intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney, which appears to be stable on serial imaging.

The patient has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse his international normalized ratio (INR). Despite this, his urine output continues to fall, and his creatinine level has risen to 5.8 mg/dL, suggesting acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to poor perfusion and acute renal failure (ARF).

The patient also has asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis, which may be related to his atrial fibrillation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 92% on 4 liters of nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (13.9 K/μL), elevated creatinine (5.8 mg/dL), and elevated blood urea nitrogen (244 mg/dL). His troponin-T level is 0.06 ng/mL, and his cardiac enzymes are normal.

The patient's imaging studies show a right pleural effusion and mild bibasilar atelectasis on chest X-ray, and a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows an intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Repeat CT scan to evaluate for interval change
* Q8 hour hemoglobin and hematocrit with PRBC transfusion for a goal of >25 and FFP transfusion for a goal of <1.9
* Hold aspirin and coumadin
* Repeat Lasix bolus for now, considering rising creatinine
* Renally dose all medications
* Continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
* Consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration pneumonia given episode of emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening chest X-ray
* Check stool guaiac if positive, will require GI consult
* Continue IV PPI for now
* Maintain active T and S
* Cycle cardiac enzymes
* Attempt rate control with metoprolol
* Consult EP for pacer interrogation
* Continue to hold ASA in setting of RP bleed
* F/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
* Continue strict I and O
* Continue scheduled albuterol and atrovent nebs
* Consider formal echo for better evaluation of cardiac function

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of renal function
* Development of sepsis or aspiration pneumonia
* Hemodynamic instability due to ongoing bleeding or hypovolemia
* Cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure
* Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
* Gout or other metabolic complications
* UGIB or gastrointestinal bleeding
* Respiratory failure or respiratory distress syndrome
* Infection or sepsis due to urinary tract or other sources

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code: presumed full
   .

   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation (AF) on coumadin, and diabetes mellitus type II (DM-II). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney.

The patient has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse his international normalized ratio (INR). His urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose Lasix boluses.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.9 g/dL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 25.3%
* Platelet count: 158 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 5.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 244 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: normal
* Troponin-T: 0.06 ng/mL
* Lactate: mildly elevated

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis: intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney, with no significant change from prior study
* Chest X-ray (CXR): mild bibasilar atelectasis and tiny right pleural effusion

The patient's clinical course is complicated by:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) with rising creatinine and blood urea nitrogen
* Intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney
* Hypoxia with evidence of volume overload on CXR
* Possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB)
* Acute on chronic renal failure (ACRF)
* Possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI)
* Fever and leukocytosis with left shift
* History of atrial fibrillation and cardiac disease

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Renal failure
* Hypovolemic shock
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Sepsis

The patient's management plan includes:

* Repeat CT scan to evaluate for interval change
* Q8 HCT with PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for goal < 1.9
* Hold aspirin and warfarin
* Continue Lasix boluses as tolerated
* Monitor urine output and adjust fluid management accordingly
* Consider renal diet when restarted
* Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO daily
* Monitor for signs of infection and sepsis
* Continue telemetry and cardiac monitoring
* Consider repeat echo and stress test to evaluate for cardiac disease

The patient's disposition is pending, but he is likely to require continued ICU care and close monitoring.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and systolic congestive heart failure.
* He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney.
* He has received 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma to support his hemodynamics and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR).
* His urine output has continued to fall, and his creatinine levels have risen, indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to poor perfusion and acute renal failure (ARF).
* He has also developed hypoxia, which is being managed with oxygen therapy, and has a history of obstructive lung disease.
* He has an atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which is being managed with rate control medications.
* He has a fever and leukocytosis, which may be related to the inflammatory response to the renal hemorrhage.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Abdominal compartment syndrome due to worsening renal function and ongoing retroperitoneal bleed.
* Continued progression of ATN and ARF, leading to worsening renal function and potential need for renal replacement therapy.
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's fever and leukocytosis.
* Aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's history of obstructive lung disease and recent episode of emesis.
* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent episode of guaiac-positive post-tussive emesis.
* Cardiac complications due to the patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and history of systolic congestive heart failure.
* Hypothyroidism due to the patient's history of hypothyroidism and potential effects of the patient's underlying medical conditions.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and renal function closely.
* Repeat CT scan to evaluate for interval change in the retroperitoneal bleed.
* Continue to trend bladder pressures to monitor for abdominal compartment syndrome.
* Hold ASA and coumadin due to the patient's bleeding risk.
* Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control medications.
* F/u blood and urine cultures and CXR to evaluate for infectious source of fever and leukocytosis.
* Consider increasing AM Lantus dosing for improved basal coverage with HISS for breakthrough.
* Contact patient's wife and primary care physician to discuss DM management.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) on coumadin, who presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain. Imaging studies revealed a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. He has received 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR). Despite this, his urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose Lasix boluses. He has also experienced asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's rising creatinine levels and sediment consistent with ATN suggest that he is at risk for further kidney damage.
2. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS): The patient's rising creatinine levels and worsening renal function, combined with his ongoing right renal parenchymal bleed, increase his risk for ACS.
3. Hypoxia: The patient's history of obstructive lung disease and requirement for BiPAP at night for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) increase his risk for hypoxia.
4. Urosepsis: The patient's history of urinary tract infection (UTI) and his current urinary retention increase his risk for urosepsis.
5. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (RVR): The patient's history of AF and his current episode of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis increase his risk for RVR.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and his current medications may increase his risk for hypothyroidism-related complications.
7. Gout: The patient's history of gout and his current medications may increase his risk for gout-related complications.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and his current requirement for oxygen therapy increase his risk for pneumonia.
9. Sepsis: The patient's history of UTI and his current urinary retention increase his risk for sepsis.
10. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of CAD and his current atrial fibrillation with RVR increase his risk for cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and urine output closely.
2. Consider further imaging studies, such as a repeat CT scan, to evaluate for interval change in the right kidney.
3. Continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of ACS.
4. Consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration pneumonia given the patient's history of COPD and his current requirement for oxygen therapy.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider further evaluation, such as a formal echo, to assess for decompensated heart failure.
6. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes and consider increasing his morning Lantus dosing for improved basal coverage.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's thyroid function and consider further evaluation, such as a thyroid function test, to assess for hypothyroidism-related complications.
8. Continue to manage the patient's gout and consider further evaluation, such as a uric acid level, to assess for gout-related complications.
9. Consider further evaluation, such as a chest X-ray, to assess for pneumonia.
10. Consider further evaluation, such as a blood culture, to assess for sepsis.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   (1)  In AM - complained of chest discomfort and shortness of breath;
   EKG was not concerning however troponins began to rise from .06 -> .12
   -> .15 with CK-MB of 6 -> 11 -> 12.  CK-MB fractions were
   non-significant. Touched base with Dr[**Name (NI) 10535**] coverage who felt this
   was likely secondary to renal failure.
   (2) Began to desaturate into the low 90s in the morning, with use of
   accessory muscles, tachycardic; was intubated.  Despite intubation, pt
   continued to desaturate into the low 80s, with HRs of 110-120; febrile
   to 101.  Felt that patient was overbreathing the vent and sedation was
   increased.  Due to continued desaturations, esophageal balloon was
   placed for more accurate measurements of transpulmonary pressures and
   determine if reduction in chest wall compliance, given abdominal
   distension.   The transpulmonary inspiratory pressure was 11 and
   expiratory pressure was 1; PEEP was increased to 25 and tidal volumes
   were decreased from 550 to 500.  ET tube was noted to be 8 cm above
   carina; was moved down 3-4 cm.  After these adjustments, blood gas was
   mildly improved with pO2 of 71 pCO2 of 35 pH of  7.34.   This morning's
   blood gas had continued improvement with pO2 of 84 pCO2 of 39 and pH of
   7.36.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He is currently in the ICU due to acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors, including:

1. Hypoxia: The patient has been desaturating on the ventilator, with PaO2s in the 70s-80s on 100% FiO2. The cause of this is unclear, but it is likely multifactorial, involving abdominal distension, pulmonary edema, and an underlying infectious process.
2. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient has an intraparenchymal/subcapsular bleed of the right kidney, possibly secondary to cyst rupture in the setting of a high INR from coumadin.
3. Acute/chronic renal failure: The patient has a creatinine of 6.4, which is an increase from his baseline creatinine of <3. He has chronic kidney disease and is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to the GI bleed and potential hypotension.
4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR): The patient has an irregular wide complex tachycardia up to 140 beats per minute, which is becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and dyspnea.
5. Fever/leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count remains elevated, which could be secondary to a pneumonia as he is growing gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci in his sputum.
6. Concern for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB): The patient has been suctioning coffee-ground material from his OG tube, which may be secondary to an old prior bleed, but the source is unclear.

The patient is being treated with the following medications:

* Azithromycin and ceftriaxone for suspected CAP
* Metoprolol for rate control
* Fentanyl and midazolam for sedation
* Norepinephrine for vasopressor support
* Calcium gluconate for CRRT
* Pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Levothyroxine sodium for hypothyroidism
* Allopurinol for gout (discontinued due to poor renal function)

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Creatinine: 6.4
* INR: 1.9
* WBC count: 15.7
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 263
* Troponin-T: 0.15
* CK-MB: 12

The patient's condition is considered high-risk due to his complex medical history, multiple organ dysfunction, and ongoing bleeding. The patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further complications.

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Was desaturating on ventilator, w/ PaO2s in the 70s - 80s on 100%
   FiO2.  Unclear what's causing low saturations but likely
   multifactorial.  Abdominal distension may reduce chest wall compliance,
   leading to hypoxemia.  Secondly, he may have underlying pulmonary edema
   given his biventricular heart failure and that he received multiple
   RBCS + FFPs.  He may also have an underlying  infectious process (white
   count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory sputum is
   growing  4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs and
   chains. Finally, the patient is frequently overbreathing the ventilator
   and appears to be in dyssynchrony with the ventilator.
   -Blood gas has improved considerably this AM on higher PEEP, lower
   tidal volumes, and adjustment of ET tube.  Could decrease FiO2 and PEEP
   as tolerated.
   -Respiratory sputum growing gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  If in next
   two days, no improvement clinically, consider switching to HAP
   coverage.
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Overall is 3 L positive.  Given that he is
   currently getting CVVH, can adjust rate of CVVH to remove -0.5
 1 L of
   fluid daily.
   -Increase sedation as necessary to reduce dyssynchrony.
   .
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - q 6  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He was admitted with acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and r/o AMI. He has been experiencing chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and desaturation on the ventilator. The patient has been treated with CVVH, FFP, and PRBC transfusions to support hemodynamics and reverse INR.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's desaturation on the ventilator may be due to abdominal distension reducing chest wall compliance, underlying pulmonary edema, or an infectious process.
2. Retroperitoneal Bleed: The patient has an intraparenchymal/subcapsular bleed of the right kidney, possibly secondary to cyst rupture, which may be exacerbated by his high INR from coumadin.
3. Acute/Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine has increased to 6.4, and he has undergone CVVH starting yesterday. He is at risk for ATN due to his chronic kidney disease, hypotension, and possible cyst rupture.
4. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has an irregular wide complex tachycardia, which is rate-controlled with metoprolol.
5. Fever/Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC continues to remain elevated, and he is growing gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci in his sputum, which may indicate pneumonia.
6. Concern for UGIB: The patient has been suctioning coffee-ground material from his OG tube, which may indicate a previous bleed, but the source is unclear.
7. DMII: The patient's sugars have been poorly controlled, and he may require an insulin drip for more optimal control.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient is taking levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg.
9. Gout: The patient is taking allopurinol.
10. FEN: The patient is at risk for fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances due to his multiple blood products and CVVH.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and adjust PEEP and FiO2 as necessary.
2. Continue to follow the patient's creatinine levels and adjust CVVH as necessary.
3. Consider switching to HAP coverage if the patient does not show improvement clinically.
4. Increase sedation as necessary to reduce dyssynchrony.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's WBC and adjust antibiotics as necessary.
6. Continue to suction the OG tube to remove any remaining coffee-ground material.
7. Consider an insulin drip for more optimal control of the patient's sugars.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust as necessary.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's INR and adjust coumadin as necessary.
10. Consider a CT scan if the patient's respiratory status improves.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying  nfectious process
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum is growing  4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in
   pairs and chains.  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  He may also have an  Finally, the
   patient is frequently overbreathing the ventilator and was previously
   in dyssynchrony with ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas considerably improved this AM on higher PEEP, lower tidal
   volumes.  Currently on 40% FiO2; could decrease PEEP as tolerated.
   Improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status improvement
   likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up and re-spiked; if by tomorrow WBC has not improved
   and has continued fevers, expand coverage to HAP.
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -2 L overnight, overall is
   now only 1 L positive.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to take off
   maximum 1 L today so to keep him at balance.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   - No need for CT for further evaluation given that HCTs have stabilized
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine has been improving 5.6 ->
   4.9 -> 4.4.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function;
   - Renal following: underwent CVVH starting yesterday.   Probably may
   have reached new baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -In addition to PR bisacodyl would add soap suds enema
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone; adding vancomycin for coverage
   of enterococcal UTI
   -F/u blood, urine, sputum cxs
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Switched to insulin drip yesterday.  Sugars over past 12 hours
   have all been 100 - 200; would continue drip given improved control.

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, atrial fibrillation, and systolic congestive heart failure. He is currently intubated and ventilated in the ICU due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and sepsis. He has been febrile and has a white blood cell count trending upwards, indicating an ongoing infectious process. The sputum Gram stain shows growth of gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci.

The patient has undergone multiple blood product transfusions, including red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma, to support his hemodynamics and reverse his elevated international normalized ratio (INR) from coumadin therapy. He has also received intravenous antibiotics, including azithromycin and ceftriaxone, to cover possible community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

The patient's abdominal distension is likely secondary to ileus, and he has been treated with PR bisacodyl and Reglan. He has also been started on vancomycin for coverage of possible enterococcal urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient has a concern for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) due to coffee-ground material suctioned from his orogastric tube, but his hemoglobin and hematocrit levels are stable, and he does not appear to have an active UG bleed.

The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which has been rate-controlled with metoprolol. He has also been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II and has been switched to an insulin drip.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and sepsis may continue to worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing infectious process may continue to worsen, leading to septic shock and multi-organ failure.
3. UGIB: The patient's history of UGIB and ongoing bleeding may continue to pose a risk for bleeding complications.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's chronic kidney disease and ongoing fluid overload may continue to worsen, leading to AKI.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may continue to require close monitoring and treatment.
6. Gout: The patient's gout may continue to require treatment and monitoring.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend continued close monitoring and treatment in the ICU, including ongoing antibiotic therapy, fluid management, and respiratory support.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He was admitted to the ICU with acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and r/o AMI. He has been febrile, with a white count trending up, and is growing 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in sputum cultures. He has been treated with azithromycin and ceftriaxone for CAP, and his blood gases have improved on higher PEEP and lower tidal volumes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely multifactorial, caused by underlying infectious processes, abdominal distension, pulmonary edema, and overbreathing the ventilator.
2. Retroperitoneal Bleed: The patient has an intraparenchymal/subcapsular bleed of the right kidney, possibly secondary to cyst rupture in the setting of high INR from coumadin.
3. Acute/Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has chronic kidney disease and is at risk for ATN due to GI bleed, hypotension, and rupture of the renal cyst.
4. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has irregular wide complex tachycardia, which is being rate-controlled with metoprolol.
5. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis are being treated with azithromycin and ceftriaxone, with plans to expand coverage if no improvement is seen tomorrow.
6. Concern for UGIB: The patient has had multiple episodes of coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube, which may be secondary to old prior bleed.
7. DMII: The patient has diabetes, which is being managed with an insulin drip.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient is being treated with levothyroxine sodium.
9. Gout: The patient's gout is being managed with allopurinol, which has been discontinued due to fluctuating renal function.
10. FEN: The patient is being managed with IV fluids, electrolyte repletion, and NPO status for possible UGIB.

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: The patient is receiving IV nutrition.
* Glycemic Control: The patient's sugars are being managed with an insulin drip.
* Lines: The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line, dialysis catheter, and multi-lumen line.
* Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has likely underlying pneumonia
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum shows 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs
   and chains.  Most likely to be community acquired since developed at
   time of admission and not coming from OSH; also not likely to be
   ventilator acquired since developed prior to being intubated.  Other
   reasons for hypoxia:  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  Finally, the patient is frequently
   overbreathing the ventilator and was previously in dyssynchrony with
   ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 20, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP as tolerated to keep PO2 sats >
   90%.  Further improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status
   improvement likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up, however respiratory status has improved and CXR
   looks resolved - continue coverage for CAP w/ ceftriaxone +
   azithromycin (day 4 of 8 day course).
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -0.8 L overnight, overall is
   total -0.8 L.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or
   just slightly negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .

   and 5.0.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function; may have reached new baseline.
   Continues to be oliguric (made 35 cc of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new

   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular

s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He was admitted with acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and r/o AMI. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His blood cultures show gram+ cocci growing in pairs and clusters, and his urine culture shows >100,000 colonies of enterococcus. His respiratory status has improved, and his CXR shows continued resolution of PNA. He is receiving antibiotics for CAP and is being covered for UTI.

Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient has likely multifactorial hypoxia, including underlying pneumonia, abdominal distension, pulmonary edema, and overbreathing the ventilator.
2. Acute/Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has steady creatinine levels between 4.0 and 5.0, indicating possible ATN due to GI bleed, hypotension, and rupture of the renal cyst.
3. Retroperitoneal Bleed: The patient has an intraparenchymal/subcapsular bleed of the right kidney, possibly secondary to cyst rupture in the setting of high INR from coumadin.
4. Abdominal Distension: The patient has likely secondary to ileus, with KUB showing lots of air and stool in the bowel.
5. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has sources of fever including CAP and UTI, and is receiving antibiotics for coverage.
6. Concern for UGIB: The patient has multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube, indicating possible old prior bleed.
7. Atrial Fibrillation with RVR: The patient has irregular wide complex tachycardia up to 140 beats per minute, becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and dyspnea.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his underlying infections and compromised immune system.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient is at risk of developing cardiac arrest due to his underlying cardiac disease and electrolyte imbalance.
4. Renal Failure: The patient is at risk of developing renal failure due to his underlying chronic kidney disease and ATN.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding due to his underlying gastrointestinal disease and anticoagulation therapy.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis due to his prolonged immobility and underlying hypercoagulability.
7. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient is at risk of developing pulmonary embolism due to his prolonged immobility and underlying hypercoagulability.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has likely underlying pneumonia
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum shows 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs
   and chains.  Most likely to be community acquired since developed at
   time of admission and not coming from OSH; also not likely to be
   ventilator acquired since developed prior to being intubated.  Other
   reasons for hypoxia:  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  Finally, the patient is frequently
   overbreathing the ventilator and was previously in dyssynchrony with
   ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 20, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP as tolerated to keep PO2 sats >
   90%.  Further improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status
   improvement likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up, however respiratory status has improved and CXR
   looks resolved - continue coverage for CAP w/ ceftriaxone +
   azithromycin (day 4 of 8 day course).
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -0.8 L overnight, overall is
   total -0.8 L.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or
   just slightly negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinines are steady between 4.0
   and 5.0.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function; may have reached new baseline.
   Continues to be oliguric (made 35 cc of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -In addition to PR bisacodyl would add soap suds enema
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   -Due to ileus and distension is having difficulties with tube feeds; if
   no resolution of ileus today, may have to consider D/C tube feeds and
   trying TPN.
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.  Started
   on vancomycin yesterday to cover this until we get sensitivities.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs which could be contaminant;  although gram
   stain shows gram + cocci so could be enterococcus.  For now, continue
   coverage with vancomycin (day 2).  Follow-up blood cultures and
   sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP (day 4 of 8 day course).
   Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a complex medical history, including coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation, and systolic congestive heart failure (CHF). He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for hypoxia, which is likely multifactorial in etiology.

The patient's recent events include a retroperitoneal bleed, which may be secondary to a ruptured renal cyst, and an abdominal distension likely due to ileus. He has also developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) with enterococcus, which is being treated with vancomycin.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 16.3, hemoglobin (Hb) of 9.0 g/dL, and creatinine (Cr) of 4.4 mg/dL. His blood gases show a pH of 7.47, pCO2 of 39, and pO2 of 114.

The patient's current medications include fentanyl, midazolam, and norepinephrine for sedation and hemodynamic support, as well as vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin for infection coverage.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, especially if his underlying pneumonia is not adequately treated.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is oliguric, which may indicate acute kidney injury (AKI). If his kidney function does not improve, he may require renal replacement therapy.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and pneumonia may lead to sepsis, which could worsen his underlying conditions and increase his risk of mortality.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's coffee-ground material suctioned from his OG tube may indicate ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen his anemia and increase his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen, leading to decreased metabolism, fatigue, and other symptoms.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's altered kidney function and fluid balance may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia or hypokalemia.
8. Infection: The patient's UTI and pneumonia may lead to secondary infections, such as respiratory or skin infections.
9. Organ dysfunction: The patient's underlying conditions, such as CHF and chronic kidney disease, may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction, such as liver or pancreatic dysfunction.
10. Mortality: The patient's complex medical conditions and underlying organ dysfunction may increase his risk of mortality.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and on anticoagulation, who is currently in the ICU with acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and possible retroperitoneal bleed. He is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) with a negative fluid balance. The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history. He has been diagnosed with pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2°C (100.8°F)
* Heart rate: 98 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 104/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 99%
* Heart rhythm: V-paced

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Endotracheal tube in place
* Cardiovascular examination shows a distant S2 heart sound
* Respiratory/chest examination shows symmetric expansion and dullness
* Abdominal examination shows soft, non-tender, and distended abdomen
* Neurologic examination shows responses to tactile stimuli, but movement and tone are not assessed

Laboratory results include:

* Creatinine: 4.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 165 mg/dL
* Glucose: 176 mg/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 16.3 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 26.7%
* Platelet count (Plt): 221 K/uL
* International normalized ratio (INR): 1.2
* Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): 24.8 seconds
* Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT): 24.8 seconds

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Acute lung injury (ALI): The patient's rapid evolution and resolution of pulmonary edema may be a sign of ALI, which can be life-threatening.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient's retroperitoneal bleed may continue to worsen, leading to hypovolemic shock and potential organ failure.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia may progress, leading to sepsis and potential organ failure.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation may lead to cardiovascular instability, including hypotension and tachycardia.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation and possible retroperitoneal bleed may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to take food by mouth and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to nutritional deficiencies.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying Klebsiella
   pneumonia; further cx by fluid overload from receiving multiple BP (has
   CHF) and abdominal distension.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 15, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP to 10, with target of getting to 5
   as tolerated to keep PO2 sats > 90%.  Improvement in consolidation
   suggests that this improvement in respiratory status is due to
   resolution of underlying infection.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered with azithromycin and ceftriaxone which should cover both
   gram + and klebsiella and atypicals.  WBC plateau'd and now falling;
   continue  ceftriaxone + azithromycin (day 5 of 8 day course).
   -Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or just slightly
   negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine continuing to resolve,
   trended down to 3.6.  Cause of ARF likely secondary to ATN secondary to
   sustained hypoTN as well as intraparenchymal bleed.  Given chronic
   kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting of GI bleed, may
   have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led to ATN.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Continues to be
   oliguric (made 5cc /hr of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Aggressive bowel regimen:   PR bisacodyl, have tried soap suds enema.
   If still failing, can try milk + molasses (brown cow)
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis - Continues to be intermittently febrile but has
   largely resolved.
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Enterococcus is sensitive to ampicillin; can switch to this and
   continue to finish 10 day course.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs is likely to be contaminant; Follow-up
   blood cultures and sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP/klebsiella PNA (day 5 of
   8 day course). Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Went up on lantus this AM.  Sugars over past 12 hours have all
   been 100 - 200.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally
   dosed)
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes; if BM occurs today can start TF;
   if no BM may have to consider TPN.
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, IV PPI
   # Access: IJ, peripherals, HD line
   # Code: full
